## Natural history notes

The Rosy Camphorweed (Pluchea baccharis) is a perennial wildflower native to wetlands, marshes, and moist meadows of the southeastern United States. It produces clusters of small, rosy-purple flower heads that attract butterflies, bees, and other pollinators. The leaves give off a distinctive camphor-like aroma when crushed, a trait that inspired its common name. By thriving in wet soils, it helps support pollinator diversity in swamp and marsh ecosystems.
